message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is on clarithromycin, which can prolong the QT interval and lead to Torsades de Pointes (TdP) ventricular tachycardia, which is shown on the ECG strip. The high potassium level (6.1 mEq/L) is also a risk factor for TdP, but the fact that the patient had QT prolongation on a previous ECG suggests that the medication is the more likely cause. Clarithromycin should be discontinued immediately in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is on clarithromycin and ceftriaxone, but only clarithromycin has been associated with QT prolongation. The laboratory studies show normal calcium and low thyroid-stimulating hormone, ruling out hypercalcemia and thyrotoxicosis. Septic shock could cause the patient’s deterioration but it’s not the most likely underlying cause based on the information provided.

The elevated potassium level (6.1 mEq/L) may also contribute to this, but the most likely cause is the medication. Hypercalcemia can also cause arrhythmia but the calcium level is within normal range. The low TSH level indicates hyperthyroidism but the patient is not exhibiting classic symptoms. Septic shock can cause similar symptoms but the medication history and ECG make drug-induced arrhythmia more likely.
